variant.question: What is meant by duplex communication?

options.text: A method in which telecommunication between two stations can take place in both directions simultaneously.
A method in which telecommunication between stations can only take place with the help of a switching centre.
A method in which telecommunication takes place in one direction, from ground stations to aircraft.
A method in which telecommunication takes place in one direction, from aircraft to ground stations.

variant.question: Considering the instrument approach, what is an APV?

options.text: Approach procedure with vertical guidance.
Automatic landing procedure with vertical guidance.
Automatic landing procedure with visual guidance.
Approach procedure with visual guidance.

variant.question: Which of the following calls is a "GENERAL CALL"?

options.text: ALL STATIONS Stephenville CONTROL.
YX-EFG, YX-FGH over.
YX-DEF Stephenville CONTROL.
YX-ABC, YX-BCD, YX-CDE Stephenville CONTROL.

variant.question: What does the term ?Expected Approach Time' mean??

options.text: The time at which ATC expects that an arriving aircraft, following a delay, will leave the holding point to complete its approach for a landing.
The time at which an arriving aircraft expects to arrive over the appropriate designated navigation aid serving the destination aerodrome.
The time at which an arriving aircraft, upon reaching the radio aid serving the destination aerodrome, will commence the instrument approach procedure for a landing.
The holding time over the radio facility from which the instrument approach procedure for a landing will be initiated.

variant.question: What does the term simplex communication mean?

options.text: Communication between two stations which takes place in one direction at a time.
Any transmission, emission, or reception of signs, signals, writing, images, and sounds.
One-way communication from aircraft to stations or locations on the surface of the Earth.
Communication between two stations that can take place in both directions simultaneously.

variant.question: What does the term 'broadcast' mean??

options.text: A transmission of information relating to air navigation that is not addressed to a specific station or stations.
One-way communication from aircraft to stations or locations on the surface of the earth.
Two-way communication between aircraft and stations or locations on the surface of the earth.
A transmission containing meteorological and operational information to aircraft engaged in flights over remote and oceanic areas out of range of VHF ground stations.

variant.question: An "Automatic Terminal Information Service" provides..

options.text: routine information to arriving and departing aircraft by means of continuous and repetitive broadcast.
weather reports related to a specific number of aerodromes located within a flight information region (FIR).
current meteorological and operational information essential for the safety of the air navigation within a FIR.
information concerning en-route weather phenomena which may effect the safety of aircraft operation.

variant.question: Which of the following is an ATS unit in charge of controlling traffic?

options.text: DEPARTURE
AIS
AFIS
ATIS

variant.question: What does the term "duplex communication" mean?

options.text: Communication between two stations that can take place in both directions simultaneously.
Communication relating to air navigation that is for all aircraft and stations within range.
One way communication from aircraft to stations or locations on the surface of the Earth.
One way communication from stations or locations on the surface of the Earth to aircraft.

variant.question: What does the term "duplex communication" mean?

options.text: Communication between two stations that can take place in both directions simultaneously.
One-way communication from aircraft to stations or locations on the surface of the Earth.
Communication relating to air navigation that is for all aircraft and stations within range.
One-way communication from stations or locations on the surface of the Earth to aircraft.

variant.question: What is the definition of an Instrument Approach procedure?

options.text: A series of predetermined manoeuvres by reference to flight instruments with specified protection from obstacles from the initial approach fix, or where applicable, from the beginning of a defined arrival route to a point from which a landing can be completed and thereafter, if a landing is not completed, to a position at which holding or en-route obstacle clearance criteria apply.

A straight in approach by reference to flight instruments from the initial approach fix, or where applicable, from the beginning of a defined arrival route to a point from which a landing can be completed and thereafter, if a landing is not completed, to a position at which holding or en-route obstacle clearance criteria apply.

A series of predetermined manoeuvres by reference to flight instruments with specified protection from obstacles from the intermediate approach fix, or where applicable, from the beginning of a defined arrival route to a point from which a landing can be completed and thereafter, if a landing is not completed, to a position at which holding or en-route obstacle clearance criteria apply.
A defined manoeuvre by reference to the FMS and HUD from the initial approach fix, or at the beginning of a defined arrival route to a point from which a landing can be completed.

variant.question: What is meant by simplex communication?

options.text: A method in which telecommunication between two stations takes place in one direction at a time.
A method in which telecommunication between several stations can take place in all directions simultaneously.
A method in which telecommunication takes place in one direction, from aircraft to ground stations.
A method in which telecommunication between two stations can take place in both directions simultaneously.

variant.question: In radiotelephony communication, what does the word "approved" mean?

options.text: Permission for proposed action granted.
I repeat for clarity or emphasis.
That is correct.
Authorized to proceed under the conditions specified.

variant.question: What standard term are you going to use to reply to an ATS message to indicate that you have understood the message, and will carry out the instructions incorporated in it?

options.text: WILCO
ACKNOWLEDGE
APPROVED
CLEARED

variant.question: You are in contact with Lille Approach and you hear the following odd transmission: "One, two, three, four, Lille Approach". What does it mean?

options.text: Lille Approach is making a radio check.
Lille approach is giving a time confirmation.
Lille approach is trying to contact aircraft with callsign 1 234.
All aircraft are asked to switch to 123.4 MHz.

variant.question: In radiotelephony communication, what does the term 'break break 'indicate?

options.text: The separation between messages transmitted to different aircraft in a very busy environment.
The separation between portions of a message transmitted to an aircraft station.
The exchange of transmissions is ended and no response is expected.
My transmission has ended but I expect a response from you.

variant.question: An ATS uses the phrase 'BREAK BREAK' . They are indicating that

options.text: i am ceasing transmission to one callsign and immediately commencing communications with  another callsign in a busy R/T environment.
I am indicating the separation between portions of the message.
An aircraft is in distress and all other transmissions must cease.
i  am shortly going on a break.

variant.question: In radiotelephony communication, what does the word ?acknowledge' mean??

options.text: Let me know that you have received and understood this message.
Repeat all of this message back to me exactly as received.
Pass me the following information.
Repeat all of your last transmission.

variant.question: In radiotelephony communication, what does the word contact mean?

options.text: Establish radio contact with (another given station).
Listen out on (frequency).
Radar contact established.
That is correct.

variant.question: In radiotelephony communication, what does the word "cancel" mean?

options.text: Annul the previously transmitted clearance.
Consider that transmission as not sent.
A change has been made to your last clearance.
Wait and I will call you.

variant.question: In radiotelephony communication, which word or phrase shall be used to indicate a separation between portions of a message?

options.text: Break.
I say again.
Stop.
Over.

variant.question: The terms OVER and OUT in radio communications are:

options.text: irregular terms in VHF.
commonly used to confirm a clearance.
irregular terms in HF.
common terms.

variant.question: What is the meaning of the phrase "Break Break" when used by an Air Traffic Services unit?

options.text: I hereby indicate the separation between messages transmitted to different aircraft in a very busy environment.
I hereby indicate that all stations shall omit read-backs.
I hereby indicate that an incident has occurred and that I will shortly cease to provide Air Traffic Services.
I hereby indicate that an urgent message has to be transmitted by any receiving station to another station with which radiocommunication has previously been broken.

variant.question: An Air Traffic Control Unit:

options.text: may instruct an aircraft to temporarily change its call sign for safety reasons when there is a risk of confusion between two or more similar call signs.
may not ask an aircraft to change its call sign after accepting the flight plan.
may require to change the call sign for safety reasons when there is a risk of confusion between two or more similar call signs providing the aircraft is on a repetitive flight plan.
must not ask an aircraft to change its call sign.

variant.question: Which of the following ATC stations provides ATC services for aircraft arriving and departing from one or more aerodromes?

options.text: Approach
Information
Control
Tower

variant.question: What standard phrase should you use to reply to an ATS message to indicate that you have understood only the first part of the message?

options.text: SAY AGAIN ALL AFTER
CHECK MESSAGE AFTER
CONFIRM ALL AFTER
READ BACK AFTER

variant.question: What standard phrase should you use to reply to an ATS message to indicate that you have understood only the first part of the message?

options.text: SAY AGAIN ALL AFTER...
CONFIRM ALL AFTER...
CHECK MESSAGE AFTER...
READ BACK AFTER...

variant.question: Which of these phrases is used if you want to communicate that a message "CONSIDER THAT TRANSMISSION AS NOT SENT"?

options.text: DISREGARD.
CANCELLING MY LAST TRANSMISSION.
FORGET IT.
CANCEL MY LAST MESSAGE.

variant.question: In radiotelephony communication, what does the word disregard mean?

options.text: Consider that transmission as not sent.
An error has been made in this transmission.
Wait and I will call you.
Annul the previously transmitted clearance.

variant.question: When transferring communications between ATSU's what is the difference between the instruction to "contact" the next unit or "call" the next unit?

options.text: If instructed to "contact" the next ATSU they will have your details whereas with a "call" your full details will need to be passed on initial contact.
If instructed to "call" the next ATSU they will require level and speed whereas with a "contact" your full details will need to be passed on initial contact.
If instructed to "call" the next ATSU they will have your details whereas with a "contact" your full details will need to be passed on initial contact.
There is no distinction between "contact" and "call". Each requires full details to be passed.
